A lamplighter is a person who used to light and extinguish street lamps before automated systems became common. They played a vital role in providing nighttime illumination in urban areas, using long poles with wicks to ignite and extinguish gas or oil lamps.

Lamplighters served an important service to their communities by illuminating the dark and often treacherous city streets. On the break of dawn, the lamplighter navigates through the labyrinth of urban alleys and avenues, enchanting a warm glow of street lamps against the enfolding darkness.

Today, there's no need for lighting lamps anymore. Lighting systems became more and more automated, making the previous wide-spread profession obsolete.

Arthur Griggs journey has ever been accompanied by the warm glow of street lamps. Stepping into a tradition held up high in his community, he enchants the dark time of day.

Through wind and weather, winter and summer, the commitment to his craft has become more than a profession; it became a proud part of his identity. He brings light, and with it, guidance and safety to his town.

Arthurs service gave him a sense of belonging, looking forward to many more years of service.   Faster than expected, technical change disrupted personal lifes, leaving a gap for many.

Traditional gas lamp work by burning natural gas. Often ignited with a burning wick attached to long poles, this creates a flame emerging a radiant light. This classic process has long graced streets with its warm and charming glow.

Modern street lamps are usually automated and make use of LED lamps. Though efficient, they usually create a strongly artificial light, leaving a less warm and personal.

The lamplighter is a metaphor for many traditional professions.
What happens, when our traditions and way of living are constantly challenged by technical advance?

All imagery in this work has been created with Stable Diffusion. This work was developed as part of the course "AI Creative Kitchen" in 2024 under the supervision of Prof. Peter Kabel, HAW Hamburg.
